review text:
This Ninja Coffee Bar dual brew unit replaced an older Ninja Coffee bar I had for about 4-5 years. The older unit was always problematic. The amount of water it used for a cup or pot always varied, and the orange time to clean light eventually always stayed on and never off. Since we had soft water in our home the problem of calcium buildup was really not a problem, but the light came on nevertheless.

This new dual brew system works, so far, perfectly. It seems that Ninja has worked out the glitches. There is no more after drip when the coffee brews. The amount of water used is perfect each time I brew. (I don't use the coffee basket much, mostly the K-cup insert with reusable stainless steel K-cups with a paper filter.) We have had the unit about 4 months now and it is working perfectly. While I don't particularly like coffee brewed with soft water, purchasing bottled water gets too pricey. Still, the coffee is generally flavorful and the cleaning light hasn't yet come on once (I assume because the unit doesn't have a build-up). If you are looking for a coffee maker that can brew both K-cups (6 to 11 oz cup), and with the K-cup unit removed (using the basket) travel mugs, and from 1/2 to a full carafe of coffee (comes with a glass carafe), you have a brewing unit that pretty-much does it all. Highly recommend. Oh, and fits under our kitchen cabinet and I can raise the K-cup lid without moving the unit.

review text:
After having to replace my latest Keurig for the 5th time in 3 years (thankfully all under warranty), I began looking for something more reliable. Don‚Äôt get me wrong. Keurig has a wonderful warranty replacement policy, but 5 times in 3 years on a $200 machine?

Ninja, of course, was at the top of my list for consideration. I have several other Ninja products that I love and have had no problems with. When I found this DualBrew, I felt it would be a great choice. My husband and I drink different blends of coffee in the morning, so k-cups work well as we can each have our favorite. In the evening, though, we both drink decaf as an after dinner treat. A pot of decaf is perfect for this and much less expensive than k-cups. If we have guests, making a large pot of coffee is also more cost and time effective.

The Ninja DualBrew, like all Ninja products we own, seems well made and is sleek and slim, taking up only a small footprint of counter space. It is tall, though, as it accommodates a large travel mug in K-cup mode, so be sure to measure if you have low hanging cabinets over the counter. The removable 60 oz water reservoir makes filling and cleaning a breeze.

In k-cup mode, 3 needles on top, instead of the usual one, ensure the coffee inside the pods gets thoroughly saturated for a better tasting brew. My previous Keurig did have 5 needles, but this Ninja was right on par taste wise. There is also a ‚Äúrich‚Äù setting for a slightly stronger brew and an ‚Äúover ice‚Äù setting as well as the classic brew that works in either k-cup or pot mode. A dial on the front allows you to choose the amount of coffee to be dispensed. The max setting for k-cups is 12 oz, but if your travel mug is larger like mine, I run the machine twice on the 8 oz setting using the same k-cup set on ‚Äúrich‚Äù. This is perfect for me, but if you want an even stronger brew you could use a new k-cup for the second brew. Coffee made in either k-cup or pot mode comes out steaming hot. Pot mode also automatically triggers a keep warm feature to keep your coffee ready to drink for up to 4 hours.

Switching between k-cups and pot is very easy. You just insert or remove the k-cup cartridge. For a pot of coffee, this Ninja uses regular #4 cone filters.

I‚Äôve only had my DualBrew for 2 months, so I can‚Äôt yet speak to longevity, but so far I‚Äôm loving it. I will update this review if anything changes.

review text:
Let me get the bad out first.. You're going to have to experiment and come up with a recipe based on this coffee makers' concept of "ounces".
It's listed as a "12-cup coffeemaker", but there are no 'cups' anywhere indicated... just presets in seemingly arbitrary ounces... with pictures of vessels you may have, but I don't.
Since 1 scoop = 6 ounces, you'd think it'd be in 6's. Nope. It's 7, 12, 18, 26, 37, 47, etc. weird.
Then there is classic vs. rich, which supposedly reduces the ounces.
At '41' ounces, mine brewed 48 ounces of water. I measured after brewing. Then I thought, well, no grounds, so let me try again with grounds.
This time I made '37' ounces on 'classic'. I got a little over 40, much closer. I still don't understand why they bother with a very specific and arbitrary number, then deliver a different amount. That irks me still.

(On a sidenote, I bought a 'binroc' grinder that had a different set of numbers/cups that was also adding to the morning math challenge. It stopped grinding properly after a month so that went back. Now I'm grinding with a simple and reliable Capresso again.)

All that said, once I figured out how much coffee it actually produced, I could then go back and figure out how many scoops to use. I now know "41 rich = 8 scoops" and "37 classic = 6 scoops" etc..

Figuring out the k-cup is a lot easier... it's just like any other. You have a fixed amount of coffee in your pod... so, more for weaker, less for stronger.

I'm not nuts about having to store the k-cup part. It doesn't really fit on top or around it easily. I knew that going in. It's a small price to pay for the option I guess. You could just as easily buy another small kcup machine that has the same footprint. So to me, this is a little bit of a gimmick unless you rarely use k-cups and have a place for the converter.

The flip-down mug holder is great, useful, and sturdy.

The pot pours a wider stream than I'm used to, but doesn't leak or dribble. I like the pouring quality. I'm not crazy about how the lid unscrews/screws in. Kind of hard to align.

I love having a reservoir instead of a pot for the source water. I think it makes the water cleaner. (psychologically) It's also convenient if you just want a little bit and old coffee is still in the pot.

The brew quality is good. I haven't noticed a significant degradation or improvement from the Hamilton Beach or pour-overs that I've tried. I can tell when beans are fresh, when they're too fine/course, etc. So in that regard, it brews well. Also, I haven't had too many grinds in my carafe... If I did, it was likely me doing something wrong.

So overall, it makes a very good cup of coffee, is easy to use (once you get it dialed-in). I like the versatility, style, and compact footprint. I never wanted to return it. It was worth figuring it out and making it work. I've had it a month or so now and will keep it until it dies.

review name: good combo for pods and grounds
review text:
I bought this because, while I like to make pour overs and such, I also like to have an instant option for K cups. You can see my old Keurig in the back. But then I also like to have a full pot option for guests or to wake up with the smell of coffee on the weekends. But I‚Äôm not putting ALL of that on my counter so I needed a solution like this Ninja DualBrew.

It was very intuitive. In fact, I didn‚Äôt even need to read the instructions to figure out how things worked or how to even get the Pod adapter out for a full carafe. The machine won‚Äôt even let you use the carafe settings (high volume of water) unless the pod adapter is removed and the brewing shower head is slid forward over the basket. So you don‚Äôt need to worry about accidentally brewing half a gallon of water into an 8 oz cup. I tried to brew my first pod cup but it let me know it needed cleaning and upon checking the quick start guide, it let me know that the Ninja needs to run a full carafe brew (only with water, no coffee) before it‚Äôs ready to be used. I did that first and then it worked. It‚Äôs nice to have a water reservoir too, as you can see my previous Keurig machine was an older simpler version that did not have a reservoir feature. There is also a coffee scoop on the left side that fits into the body of the machine and comes off and on easy.

There are multiple brew modes including classic, rich, and over ice, each brewing differently. There is a flip down cup stand for smaller cups to reduce splatter. While a lot of Mr. Coffee machines have a spring loaded closing valve to stop the flow of coffee if you pull the carafe out mid-way, the Ninja features a manual lever that slides left to right just under the main screen. At first, I though this was a shortcoming and wondered what would happen if I forgot to flip it over and the water started overflowing in the basket. But after reading the guide, I found that the machine will stop actively brewing while it is closed and after a short period of time, if you do not flip it back, it will beep to let you know. If you don‚Äôt flip it back after five minutes, it will cancel the brew altogether. So it actually ends up being a great feature and safer than forgetting it and letting the basket overflow. The hotplate also has a light up warning to let you know it‚Äôs warm and the ninja adjusts the heat depending on the size of the brew and how long it will stay on the plate to avoid burning the coffee.

All in all, lot‚Äôs of cool features, some physical, some in the software that runs it. Intuitive to use and feels like a quality machine from a quality brand.

review text:
I understand that in any manufacturing process, there will be a certain number of defects. So I'm not going to write a big, angry review. This is just a data point for people buying this product.

But yeah... my Ninja broke after a few months. I wasn't doing anything unusual with it - just brewing 4-6 kcups/day. There was a new squeaky noise emitting from its plumbing one day. And it flashed the message indicating it needed cleaning. I ran two clean cycles following instructions, but the device remained stuck in a mode where it always recommended cleaning and would not brew kcups. (There is a separate mode for brewing full pots that continues to work.)

I'm not interested in getting repairs or replacements under warranty, because I value my time in dealing with this and any future maintenance. I'm just switching to a different brand to see if somebody else has a more reliable design/manufacturing process.

If the device didn't break down on me, my review would be like this:
* it generally does everything it claims to do reasonably well
* there is a separate part that houses the kcup which looks easily replaceable. As the mechanical operations around puncturing the kcup seem most likely to break, I like that I can replace this part without buying a whole new machine.
* the device won't work with most (any?) reusable kcups because it punctures into the kcup via 3 "fangs" rather than the typical 1 that punctures the center of the kcup.
* the UI (buttons, screen, lights) is a little cluttered and occasionally confusing. I spent one morning troubleshooting to figure out that I'd accidentally closed a valve. Maybe too many options?
* the water sensor often complains that more water is needed incorrectly, but you can ignore that warning and hit the brew button again
* the beeps that the device makes are loud, and I wish that I could turn them off. Particularly, the "all done" beeps. It happens that in my house, the device is near a couch that someone is often sleeping on.

I wish the Ninja had worked out for me. I might have just had bad luck, but there are a few hints of low engineering quality. I wish Amazon would provide metrics around long-term product failures so that we don't have to rely on anecdotal evidence like mine.

review name: Perfect for anyplace where versatility is important
review text:
I received both this version of the new Ninja Coffeemaker and the more expensive version that also makes hot water and has a frother. Due to a problem with the more expensive version, this was the one where I was actually able to see the concept in action. To be frank, unless you are very pressed for counter space, I think I'd choose this version. If I wanted clean hot water and frothy milk in addition to many versions of coffee, I'd have a separate frother that would also heat the milk, and one of the wonderful new induction kettles that are available for modest prices for any hot water I needed.

So, the downsides of this version of the Ninja Coffeemaker are that you are forced to have the water container on the side and can't move it to the back to save counter space. You don't have a separate hot water button, so you either have to have a separate kettle for absolutely clean hot water, or it will flow through the coffee section and might pick up a few stray coffee grounds. And, you won't be able to froth milk with the same machine as you use to make your coffee.

On the plus side, besides the money you'll save, the rest of the device works exactly the same as the more expensive one, and also, the choices you have are always present and readable on the face of the coffeemaker. Since I don't use pods, I took that part of the machine off and easily slid the section forward that holds the coffee grounds. There is a handy measuring spoon with guides for the amount of grounds to use for different drink sizes. It's easy to fold down the device that holds your cup rather than use the large carafe. If you want to have absolutely fresh grounds to use, you will need a separate grinder, but you can get quite good ones that are small and not terribly expensive if you are a purist! And, you will need to have a supply of paper cone inserts on hand.

After that, it's simple. Fill the water to the top mark. I like the fact that it's much easier to fill from a pitcher without spilling water all over the place as I always tended to do with old Mr. Coffee. The machine will only use the amount of water necessary to make the drink you choose, so you don't need to be exact -- just fill it up! Choose the brew you want. Specialty drink recipes will make very strong coffee that can be diluted with flavorings, and the "rich" selection will also make stronger coffee when you use a lot of milk. These choices mean that you might think this coffee is as good as you would get from a French Press or even an expresso maker. One thing I want to try is the iced coffee choice. You will actually get cold coffee over ice -- not hot coffee that will melt half your ice and dilute the coffee!

I found it very simple to choose not only the brew I wanted, classic for a smooth non-acidic drink or rich to use with a lot of milk in my case. By choosing the size of container, I could get a small or large cupful, or part of a pot. And of course, for several coffee drinkers or to fill a thermos, I could choose an entire pot of coffee. It took a very short time for the machine to heat up and start making coffee. This coffee machine has a brew style option (classic, rich or over ice), a hot water function, a programmable clock, drip stop indicators, a "keep warm" function, "smart sensing", an additional measuring cup, attached to the side of the machine, a calibration brew to determine the heat setting for your altitude and the ability to brew K-cups or filtered coffee. This coffee machine has been the best coffee machine that I have had to date. Not only does this machine come with a very thorough manual but it also arrives with a Quick Start Guide for those who do not want to flip through the manual in its entirety right at the beginning of receiving it.
